intro: Trochocarpa clarkei, commonly known as the Clarke's bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, tubular flowers that range in color from white to pale blue. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine habitats, where it thrives in well-drained soils and cool climates. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. The species is of interest to botanists due to its unique floral structure and ecological adaptations.
